Abstract#1: People in shadows, next to a wall with graffiti, outside the 7th Circle Music Collective.
Abstract#2: [caption by photographer:] Location: 7th Circle Music Collective; Date: 2018; Event: Product Lust show with a few other bands; Notes: It was snowing, a very young very positive crowd. Steam was billowing out the side door into the yard littered with detritus and graffiti. 7th Circle is one of the longest running DIY spaces in Denver. The collective runs the space in such a socialized, organized, and democratic way through out the year there could be on average, 5 shows per week celebrating both local and touring bands.

Abstract#1: Colin Ward, white artist and event organizer in the Denver community, opening a refrigerator door at Rhinoceropolis.
Abstract#2: [caption by photographer:] Location: Rhinoceropolis; Date: 2014; Notes: A show I attended with Tom Murphy. We were the only ones there and the artist’s van broke down on the way to Denver so they never showed up. I was sitting at a table when Colin Ward, (one of the main organizers, musicians, and curators of the venue) was getting something out of the fridge. Colin was an instrumental figure in the DIY community. He contributed greatly to the scene as an artist, musician, and event organizer. His passing in 2018 sent shock waves through the community. A foundation was set up in his honor the Colin Richard Ferguson Ward Fund. Rest in peace friend.

Extent#1: 1 black and white photograph; 3300 x 2200 pixels
Abstract#1: Germain Baca, white drummer for the traveling band "Josh Taylor's Friends Forever," playing the drums in a Volkswagen van.
Abstract#2: [caption by photographer:] Location: Monkey Mania II; Date: 2005; Event: Josh Taylor’s Friends Forever, Fisher Mystic, Pretty Thigh, Ultra Boyz and Nightshark Notes: The space as the first floor of a condemned building on 2126 Arapahoe Street St in Denver. For over a decade it served as a DIY space. Friends Forever was an evolving band that changed members founded by Josh Taylor. The original line-up was Josh Taylor, Jason Isaacs and Nate Hayden. I believe in 2001 Josh Taylor’s fired everyone in the band including himself and then Amy Fantastic, Germaine Baca and Kenna (not sure on a last name) became “Josh Taylor's Friends Forever” who were around for a few years. All of the versions performed out of a Volkswagen Van that acted as a mobile performance space. Often pulling up to venues unannounced and playing in the street. Performances involved improvisation, fireworks and occasionally nudity. Featured drummer Germain Baca who also played in the infamous Rainbow Sugar, as well as Sin Desires Marie.
Subject Geographic#1: Denver (Denver, Colorado, United States, North America) (populated place)

Title#1: Kalyn (Wheelchair Sports Camp), Big Queer Dance Party Part II, Glob
Abstract#1: Kalyn Heffernan (left), rapper and frontwoman with osteogenesis imperfecta, poses with her date (right) at the Big Queer Dance Party.
Abstract#2: [caption by photographer:] Location: Glob; Date: 2015; Event: Big Queer Dance Party; Notes: Kalyn Heffernan (Wheelchair Sports Camp) with date at Big Queer Dance party at a area I created for shooting portraits of the attendees. The DIY spaces were often venues for performers and artists who felt marginalized by traditional cis male dominated music venues. Piper Rose was one of the main organizers behind Big Queer Dance party, there was also Damn Gurl which was organized by Lauren Zwicky. These were some of the celebrated queer centered dance parties for the LGBTQIA community at the time.

Abstract#1: Two bicycles leaning against a wall with a mural.
Abstract#2: [caption by photographer:] Location: Monkey Mania II; Date:2005; Event: Josh Taylor’s Friends Forever, Fisher Mystic, Pretty Thigh, Ultra Boyz and Nightshark; Notes: One of Monkey Mania II last shows. The space the brain child of Josh Taylor and Amy Fantastic. Over the years they had two different locations. The venue was a destina- tion for a variety of performers, everything from noise bands to performance artists. Nate Hayden painted the amazing murals. Was the same location as the Arapaho Warehouse from the 90s also known as “The Warehouse”.

Abstract#1: Holle Finch, white band member for Pauline Heresy, singing into a microphone with two additional band members playing guitar and the drums.
Abstract#2: [caption by photographer:] Location: Acoma House; Date: 1997; Event: Pauline Heresy; Notes: Holle Finch front person of Pauline Heresy (which became Sin Desires Marie) belting one out at DIY space the Acoma House. The Acoma House was my personal introduction to the DIY punk scene of Denver. I moved there from New York in 1996 and was introduced to the scene. It was a fairly prolific venue where many local and touring bands played from 1995-1999.
Note#1: [caption by photographer:] The Acoma House was a DIY venue in Denver Colorado, active from 1995 through 1998. Many artists and musicians lived there and a countless number of bands played in our living room. This was my introduction to the music scene here. I had an opportunity to live there in 1996 and I became one of the artists helping organize shows. Bands from all over America played and often slept on our floor. Local bands like Christie Front Drive, and pictured here The Pauline Heresy played and acts such as Jimmy Eat World, Texas as the Reason, The Locust, Hot Water Music all slept on our floor. It was a vibrant time for our music scene despite the less than ideal conditions of many of these venues. We acted out of the sheer tenacity to build a sustainable creative community in what ever spaces were made available to us.
Subject Geographic#1: Denver (Denver, Colorado, United States, North America) (populated place)
Physical Location#1: University of Colorado Boulder Libraries Rare and Distinctive Collections

Title#1: Piper Rose, Big Queer Dance Party, Glob
Abstract#1: Piper Rose, white event organizer for Titwrench, sitting in a chair at the Big Queer Dance Party.
Abstract#2: [caption by photographer:] Location: Glob; Date: 2015; Event: Big Queer Dance party; Notes: Queer event organizer Piper Rose looking like a boss. They helped coordinate many events often MCing Titwrench. A powerful activist in the LGBTQIA community. Someone who helped me find my voice as a photographer.
Note#1: [caption by photographer:] I met Piper Rose through Titwrench where she would often MC the various events. She was another person who changed my life. She began organizing parties centered around fem and non binary groups. The fact that any of these people gave me the opportunity, and trusted me to document these beautiful events was formidable. This was an opportunity for people of all ages and sexual orientations to meet and thrive in a more accepting inclusive community within the DIY spaces, free of prejudice. Some of the early parties were called “Damn Gurl” and “Big Queer Dance Party”. Often I would set up a photo installation area and document all the participants.
Subject Geographic#1: Denver (Denver, Colorado, United States, North America) (populated place)

Title#1: Titwrench Madeline Johnston (Mid Wife), Mercury Café
Abstract#1: Madeline Johnston, white musician, playing a guitar with a telephone receiver used as a microphone.
Abstract#2: [caption by photographer:] Location: Mercury Café; Date: 2016; Event: Tit Wrench; Notes: Midwife (Madeline Johnston) performing at the Mercury Café. She is an integral person in the history of Denver DIY communities. Very much a part of the Glob/Rhinocer- polis families, cutting her teeth in the DIY spaces, has since moved to New Mexico. Now a full time musician who tours the world and has a international following. Mercury Café maybe one of the longest running punk venues in Denver. Founded in 1975 by Marilyn Megenity the space has a amazing history, supporting everything from punk rock to poets to swing dancing. Currently under new ownership the torch has been passed as it is still thriving.
